stream_context.summary: Kaze finishes and polishes a key overworld-facing mission thread (the Bone Dragon tooth quest), prototypes a new progression mechanic (“money hole” coin sink) to obtain a gold tooth, discusses the transition from overworld work to side-level production, and clarifies technical/release constraints around emulator compatibility (especially Parallel/RetroArch) and a plan to ship with a pre-configured emulator or recomp build. He also checks in on Biobak’s Course 15 progress and recruits for side levels.
stream_context.significance_reason: Kaze signals the overworld phase is nearly over, declares Bone Dragon phase one “works,” lays out a concrete side-level backlog, begins actively recruiting side-level builders, and frames the project as close to MVP completion (with multiplayer planned after MVP).

findings.summary: Kaze states there are “not many overworld streams left” and expects to transition soon to primarily side-level streams.
findings.quote: There are not many overworld streams left… Soon we're gonna only do side-level streams.

findings.summary: He believes the project is close to Minimum Viable Product (MVP): once side levels are done, the game is ‘finished’ in MVP terms, though substantial reworks will still remain afterward.
findings.quote: Once the side levels are done, the game's finished. The minimum viable product is finished.

findings.summary: Kaze sets a rough schedule expectation: he is “fairly confident” MVP will be finished this year, but not confident the fully reworked/polished final game will be finished this year.
findings.quote: I am fairly confident that this year we are going to finish minimum viable product… but… I don't think we will finish the entire game this year.

findings.summary: Bone Dragon quest design is clarified: phase one involves breaking a rotten tooth to relieve pain; phase two is giving the Bone Dragon a gold tooth, after which he becomes friendly and leads the player to a side level (Rising Lava).
Kaze pivots the Bone Dragon from a talk-heavy NPC toward a more monster-like presentation, deciding he likely should not ‘talk’ (to avoid over-telegraphing and to preserve tone).
findings.quote: I don't want him to talk… I like that he's just a monster.

findings.summary: To better signal the ‘break the tooth’ affordance, Kaze accepts a readability hint: adding a star-like shine/visual cue to the tooth so players suspect it’s interactable/valuable.
findings.quote: I personally was wondering how to make sure the player thinks to break his tooth… a star shine is a good idea.

findings.summary: Kaze implements/iterates Bone Dragon phase one behaviors: hitboxes, damage tuning (big slam should deal ~3 damage), sound timing, and camera/cutscene considerations; he notes camera becomes “nonsense” when the NPC interaction triggers and considers special camera cutscenes.

He invents a new progression/coin-sink mechanic (“money hole”) as the method to acquire the gold tooth: the player donates coins into a pit (like a wishing well), tracked cumulatively; after a large threshold (example floated: ~2000 coins), the gold tooth spawns and the hole permanently closes.
findings.quote: So you literally pay for this Bone Dragon's new teeth.

findings.summary: Kaze identifies implementation friction for the money hole: the game must persist/track how many coins the player has donated over time, and he needs a selection/menu UI for choosing how many coins to donate at once (he suggests allowing up to 999 at a time).
He shares the intended overall scope: ~200 stars and 3 Bowser levels, targeting ~3–4× the length of original Mario 64.

Kaze enumerates a concrete backlog of side levels still needed (small, focused experiences), including: Bowser’s Golf Course (cannon ‘golf’ through rings/holes), Rising Lava (Bone Dragon unlock), Bowser’s Yacht, Conspiracy Theory Yoshi’s House (secret cave), Manta Ray Surfing (timed linear), Wing Cap level (concept TBD), Cloud Cap level, Yoshi Race Stadium (multiple stadiums), Shy Guy Seeks (hide-and-seek around a large tree), Rolling Pinball, Pepperfruit level (speed fruit), Shell Diving vs Shark, and a big planetary gravity level (in progress by Sam).
Kaze actively recruits external level builders for side levels, with a clear condition: contributors must agree Kaze may rearrange or modify their level for fit/quality.
findings.quote: If you do make a side level, you will have to consent to me possibly rearranging your level.

findings.summary: He articulates a design philosophy aligned with Mario 64: he rejects a conventional ‘hard mode,’ arguing Mario 64’s difficulty comes from player-chosen risk rather than enforced difficulty settings.
findings.quote: Hard mode is antithetical to Mario 64's design… You get to choose your own difficulty by making more or less risky moves.

findings.summary: Release/compatibility stance: Kaze prioritizes correctness on N64 hardware and on a recommended accurate emulator (e.g., Simple64/Iris), is frustrated with Parallel/RetroArch instability, and notes a romhacking.com rule requiring Parallel compatibility—if RTYI doesn’t work on Parallel, he may avoid uploading there.
findings.quote: As long as it works on N64 and the emulator I recommend, it is what it is.

findings.summary: He plans to distribute the game with a pre-configured emulator so players can “download the exe and play,” and he’s considering a ‘plug-and-play’ recompilation build (referencing Wiseguy’s recomp approach).
findings.quote: I'm planning to release the game together with a pre-configured emulator… Maybe even like a recompilation version… which also just plug and plays.

biobak.summary: Biobak reports Course 15 progress status: the water area is done; remaining work includes plants and a motorcycle, and the rocket is a major time sink that took significant polishing effort.

zeina.summary: Kaze notes a mismatch between his intent and Zeina’s implementation on an animation tweak (the Bone Dragon flinch/timing), implying quick iteration and occasional miscommunication on animation direction.
zeina.quote: I think Zeina misunderstood the idea.

findings.summary: Kaze indicates ZeroVolt is producing music ‘boards’/music-related deliverables for RTYI (framed as ongoing music pipeline work).
Kaze says Sam is currently building the “big planetary gravity” side level and that it already looks promising.
findings.quote: Sam is currently making one… She's making the gravity one.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: Once the side levels are done, the game's finished. The minimum viable product is finished.
memorable_quotes.context: Defines what ‘MVP’ means for RTYI and frames the project’s endgame structure (main content vs. reworks/polish).

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I am fairly confident that this year we are going to finish minimum viable product… but… I don't think we will finish the entire game this year.
memorable_quotes.context: Clear, documentary-useful forecast distinguishing playable completion from full polish/rework completion.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: Hard mode is antithetical to Mario 64's design… You get to choose your own difficulty by making more or less risky moves.
memorable_quotes.context: Articulates the team’s respect-for-the-classic philosophy: difficulty emerges from movement choice and player agency.

key_stories.title: Bone Dragon mission design: from tooth break to gold-tooth unlock
key_stories.summary: Kaze finalizes a two-phase mission arc around the Bone Dragon: first, you break a rotten tooth (with clearer visual signaling via star shine), then you later acquire and deliver a gold tooth to befriend the creature. Befriending the Bone Dragon is a traversal/progression beat that leads the player into a dedicated side level (Rising Lava).
key_stories.challenge: The tooth interaction needed to read clearly to players (so they try breaking it), and the ‘how do you get a gold tooth’ question needed a progression mechanism that fits the world and economy.
key_stories.process: Kaze iterates on hitboxes, damage, sounds, and camera behavior for phase one; he debates whether the Bone Dragon should talk; he adds a star-like highlight to hint the tooth matters. He then brainstorms acquisition methods (initially a smith who appears after a course), but pivots to a coin-sink ‘money hole’ wishing-well mechanic.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze states phase one ‘works’ and moves on to phase two planning/implementation: a cumulative coin-donation system that spawns the gold tooth after a threshold, permanently closing the money hole afterward.
key_stories.key_quote: So you literally pay for this Bone Dragon's new teeth.

key_stories.title: Emulator compatibility vs. creator priorities: shipping with a pre-configured way to play
key_stories.summary: Kaze vents about the fragmented emulator ecosystem and recurring instability/bugs around Parallel/RetroArch, while emphasizing his primary target is real N64 hardware and a recommended accurate emulator. To reduce friction and support plug-and-play, he proposes shipping RTYI with a pre-configured emulator executable and possibly a recomp build.
key_stories.challenge: Players will try many emulator stacks (Parallel Launcher, random RetroArch plugins), creating unpredictable bug reports and potential negative reception even when the game itself is correct on hardware.
key_stories.process: Kaze tests/compares emulator performance and behavior, cites constraints from a romhacking.com rule (Parallel compatibility expectation), and explores packaging strategies to standardize the play environment (pre-configured emulator or recomp).
key_stories.outcome: A clear distribution direction emerges: guide players toward a known-good configuration, and if Parallel compliance becomes mandatory for certain platforms, avoid those uploads rather than contort the project around unstable emulator behavior.
key_stories.key_quote: I'm planning to release the game together with a pre-configured emulator… so that you can just download the exe and play.

open_questions.topic: Definition of MVP vs. ‘entire game’ completion
open_questions.context: Kaze says MVP is achieved once side levels are done, but also says there are many reworks afterward and he doubts the ‘entire game’ will be done this year.
questions: What exactly is included in RTYI’s MVP build (which worlds/courses, which cutscenes, which bosses, which side levels)?
What categories of ‘reworks’ remain after MVP (level layout, art pass, performance, writing, camera/cutscenes, difficulty tuning, collectibles economy)?
What internal criteria decides ‘MVP is done’ versus ‘the game is done’?

open_questions.topic: Money hole (coin sink) implementation and economy tuning
open_questions.context: Kaze proposes a cumulative coin-donation mechanic (possibly ~2000 coins) to spawn the gold tooth, with an option to donate up to 999 at once, but notes persistence/tracking is annoying and needs a special approach.
questions: Where will the donation total be stored (save file, per-level state, global flags), and how will it handle multiple save slots?
How was the threshold (e.g., 2000 coins) chosen, and how does it affect the overall coin economy across 200 stars?
Will there be alternative ways to earn/convert coins late-game to avoid grinding (minigames, repeatables, exchange systems)?
How will the UI/menu for selecting donation amounts work within SM64’s dialog/menu constraints?

open_questions.topic: Bone Dragon presentation: monster vs. NPC readability and camera language
open_questions.context: Kaze changes his mind about having the Bone Dragon ‘talk’ and also notes the camera becomes nonsense during interaction, implying a custom camera/cutscene may be required.
questions: What final tone is desired for Bone Dragon—sympathetic creature, comedic setpiece, or threatening monster with implied empathy?
How will the game teach the player the tooth can be broken without explicit dialog (shine, placement, animation, sound cues)?
What is the final camera plan for the tooth-break moment and the befriend/lead-to-side-level moment?

open_questions.topic: Side-level production pipeline and external contributor management
open_questions.context: Kaze lists many unbuilt side levels and invites others to build them, requiring consent that he may rearrange their work; he references Sam’s gravity level and encourages Sunny to pick a nature/forest-themed level like Shy Guy Seeks.
questions: What is the spec for a ‘side level’ (expected duration, star count, asset budget, performance targets, unique mechanic requirement)?
What tools and handoff format do outside contributors use (Fast64 workflow, repo process, review steps, acceptance criteria)?
How does Kaze decide when to ‘rearrange’ a contributor’s level, and how are creative disagreements handled?

open_questions.topic: Distribution strategy: pre-configured emulator vs. recomp build and platform rules
open_questions.context: Kaze plans to ship a pre-configured emulator executable and considers Wiseguy-style recomp for plug-and-play. He also mentions a romhacking.com requirement for Parallel compatibility and suggests skipping that platform if necessary.
questions: What exact bundle will ship with RTYI (patch only, patch + launcher, pre-configured Simple64/Iris, optional recomp executable)?
How will you message ‘supported’ vs. ‘unsupported’ emulator setups to reduce support load and negative reviews?
What is the current state of Parallel compatibility for RTYI, and what would it cost (in dev time/constraints) to maintain it?
